This is one of the finest topic in discreet mathematics and it's application. Linear and Non-Linear Recurrences are also important in Computer Science, Math and Engineering. I hope that each MIT student in Computer Science, Math and Engineering benefit  from these important concepts.

This comment is about "guessing" the particular solution in solving recurrences.  I read about this topic in "Discrete Math. and Its Applications by Kenneth H. Rosen" and in Ch.8.2 it actually states a theorem (Theorem 6) that gives a rule for what the particular solution for non-homogenous will be. So there is no need to guess and see if it fails then guess again and so on... (as far as I understood the theorem).  I hope someone corrects me if I'm wrong.

Because it means any value of 'b' satisfies the conditional equation. You put b=1.356, doesn't matter, it goes away; put b=.0001, doesn't matter, it goes away. So you put b=0 just to make the calculation of 'c1' simple. I suggest you put b=2 and then solve for the general equation yourself, you'll get the same answer with a different 'c1' other than lecture. Just do it, you'll realize yourself.
